 There has been no improvement in unemployment. The unemployment rate has dropped due to increasing numbers of discouraged workers and people dropping out of the work force because they can not find jobs. 
 
 It is even worse than that. We need to generate about 150,000 jobs per month just to keep up with population growth. We have not been generating those jobs, so those people are not becoming newly employed, so they are never counted as part of the workforce. There is no accounting for them AT ALL, even though they are available to work, want to work, and just cant FIND work. Even worse, most of these are recent college graduates, so they are RAPIDLY losing any skills they may have picked up in college. 
 
 If you include all the unemployed (discouraged workers, etc...) and figure an additional 150,000 per month due to birth/death model (this is what most economists use, even though they know it is probably a little on the low side), real unemployment is running close to 18% right now. 
 
 I dont think there is any question that the stimulus has provided the illusion of economic improvement. Throw enough money at the economy and numbers go up. The real test of how well it worked is what happens when you STOP throwing money at the economy. If you look at the monetary growth since the economic crisis, the US would have to have grown at an annual rate of 32% to justify that much monetary creation. 
 
 Today we found out that PIMCO, the largest bond fund in the world, has completely dumped not only treasuries, but US agency debt as well from their flagship fund. They literally came out and said "US government debt is too risky to hold". This is not some little nothing mutual fund...this is PIMCO, with over 1.1 trillion in assets. 
 
 They dumped them because QE2 is scheduled to end in June, and the fed has been the buyer of 70% of US treasuries sold since the financial crisis began. When they stop buying, there is pretty much nobody out there with the confidence in the US economy to step up and replace them. The chinese, and even the Arabs are desperately trying to get rid of US government paper. 
 
 This is the problem with this kind of intervention. If you can intervene in cash and get the economy over a rough patch, then you should. This was not a rough spot. We needed a fundamental realingment in the US economy. Instead of doing it, we treated it as a really BIG rough spot and threw a fortune at it, but it is all debt. It is like borrowing a million dollars to buy a ford taurus.
